message: TimeOut should be specified as a long

body: @kcooney Sorry, I couldnt work out how to remove those changes, so have submitted another pull request and closed the previous one (#446).  Hopefully, I've covered all of your points?
Looks good to me. Assigning to David

@davidhart82 @kcooney 
IMHO you should see the implementation of ReentrantLock in JDK source code, they always convert to nanos internally and use Thread.join(long millis, int nanos).
In such approach you should convert opposite Timeout(long millis) -> toNanos(), and add one more constructor FailOnTimeout(Statement base, long timeout, TimeUnit unit)
internally convert to nanos as private final field in FailOnTimeout.

This way we are able to use microseconds which is realistic delay, and for the future of cpu enhancements.

You can still use long which handles nanos, because the max delay will be then 292 years, enough isn't it.

@Tibor17 That sounds like a different pull request.

Let's see what David says about the use of TimeUnit in JUnit when he
returns from leave. It should be easy to change the internal representation
of the timeout later.

- Kevin
On Jun 13, 2012 5:16 AM, "Tibor17" <
reply@reply.github.com>
wrote:

> IMHO you should see the implementation of ReentrantLock in JDK source

message:
Re-introduce int constructor

Try not to break binary compatibility; re-introduce int constructor.
Add test for global Timeout now taking a long and TimeUnit in the constructor

body: Sorry for the delay.  It looks like there's now a merge conflict.  Can you resolve the conflict?  Thanks.
@davidhart82 Can you please merge your branch with KentBeck/master so we can merge your pull request? Would really like to have this in the soon to be released 4.11.
